summary: PRRS virus (PRRSV) is an enveloped, nonsegmented, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus belonging to the genus Rodartevirus, the family Arteriviridae, and the order Nidovirales (3). the PRRSV genome is 15.4 kb in length and contains at least 11 open reading frames (ORFs) PRRSV interferes with the induction and function of IFN by using an N protein or nsps (10, 11) PRRSV blocks nuclear translocation of STAT 1 and STAT2, leading to the inhibition of IFN-activated JAK-STAT signaling (12). however, the mechanisms of immune evasion by PRRSV have not been fully characterized. SOCS1 and SOCS3 strongly suppressed TLR7-mediated type I IFN production. previous studies indicated that SOCS protein expression is classically induced by cytokines, especially type I IFNs. CS1 affected PRRSV replication as well as the underlying mechanism of SOCS production. PRRSV-induced SOCS1 production was not due to classical IFN signaling but required p38/AP-1 and JNK/AP-1 signaling pathways. m.nih.gov/nuccore/KX766378.1) and the NADC30-like strain HNhx (GenBank ID: KX766379, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nuccore/KX766379) were previously isolated by our laboratory in 2007 and 2016, respectively, in china (45–47) the low-pathogenic PRRSV strain BJ-4 (GenBank ID: AF33 FN- and IFN- were purchased from PBL Assay Science and PeproTech. Protease inhibitor (cOmplete, EDTA-free, EASYpack of 20) was purchased from Beyotime. luciferase reporter (IFN-–Luc) was constructed in our laboratory (51) table I. Primers used in cloning in this study. a 2.1-kb fragment of the SOCS1 promoter flanking the 5′ region of the SOCS1 gene was amplified by PCR from swine genomic DNA. the clone sequences are found at nt 31877143–31879242 of the Sus scrofa genome. 104AP-1-Luc and 104AP-1-Luc were constructed in pGL4.17-basic by Sangon Biotech. membranes were blocked for 1 h in 5% skimmed milk and incubated with primary Abs. pcDNA3.1-Myc/His_A was used as a control. the cells were lysed for Western blotting using primary anti-His Ab. luciferase reporter assays, titer determinations, and quantitative real-time PCR. GAPDH was set up as an endogenous control. gene-specific primers are listed in Table II. small interfering RNA knockdown The specific small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) against SOCS1 (siSOCS1-1: 5′-CCU GCA CGG AGC AUU AAC UTT-3′; siSOCS1-2: 5′-GCC GAC AAU GCA AUC UCC ATT-3′). a scrambled negative control (NC) RNA was synthesized by GenePharma. the cells were transfected with siRNA against SOCS1, IFNAR1, c-Jun, c-Fos, or NC. twenty-four hours later, the cells were infected with PRRSV at a multiplicity of infection. at 24 h postinfection, cells were lysed, and luciferase activities were measured. cells were transfected or mock transfected with poly(I:C) for 12 h. pGL4.17-basic was used as a control of reporter plasmid. soluble type I IFNR B18R and signaling pathway inhibitors toward porcine AMs or Marc-145 cells were determined using a cellTiter 96 AQueous One Solution Cell Proliferation Assay. the cells were incubated with a fresh medium containing the tetrazolium compound. the cells were further incubated at 37°C for 2 h under a humidified atmosphere containing 5% CO2. cells and viruses Marc-145 cells were maintained in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS (Life Technologies), 100 U/ml penicillin, and 100 g/ml streptomycin. primary porcine alveolar macrophages (AMs) were obtained from lung lavage of 4- to 6-wk-old specific pathogen-free piglets. cbi.nlm.nih.gov/nuccore/AF331831) and PRRSV strain GZ11-G1 belong to PRRSV-2 species. heat-inactivated HN07-1 (Heat-HN07-1) was generated by incubating strain HN07-1 in a water bath at 65°C for 1 h. codon-optimized porcine SOCS1 gene was synthesized and subcloned into pEGFP-C1 vector to generate pEGFP-SOCS1 construct. SOCS1 was also amplified using pEGFP-SOCS1 as template and subcloned into pcDNA3.1-Myc/His_A to generate pcDNA3.1-SOCS1-His. ACTCAAAAGC-3′ Nsp4 R 5′-GCTCTAGATTCCAGTTCGGGTTTTTGGCAGC-3′ Nsp5 F 5′-GGGGTACCATGGGAGGTCTCAAC-3′ Nsp5 R 5′-GCTCTAGACTCGGCAAGAAG-3′ N (142–372 nt) a 2.1-kb fragment of the SOCS1 promoter flanking the 5′ region of the SOCS1 gene was amplified by PCR from swine genomic DNA. the clone sequences are found at nt 31877143–31879242 of the Sus scrofa genome. the pRL-TK Renilla luciferase reporter plasmid was used as an endogenous control. membranes were blocked for 1 h in 5% skimmed milk and incubated with the appropriate primary Abs for 1 h at room temperature. the membranes were then incubated with the appropriate secondary Abs for 1 h. 2834-CD163 cells were measured using a commercially available ELISA kit. in brief, porcine AMs were collected from tissue culture dishes and centrifuged at 500 g at 4°C for 10 min. the final pellets were resuspended in PBS containing 1 protease inhibitor and 1 mM NaF. the cell lysates were subjected to three freeze-thaw cycles. CS1 F 5′-CGCCCTCAGTGTGAAGATGG-3′ Porcine SOCS1 R 5′-GCTCGAAGAGAG-3′ Porcine IFN- F 5′-TGCAACCACCACAATTCC-3′ Porcine IFN- F 5′-TGCAACCACCACAATTCC-3′ Porcine IFN- F 5′-TGCATGAAGATGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGCGC AAGCAGTT-3′ Monkey ISG56 F 5′-ACGTAACTGAAAATCCACAAGA-3′ Monkey OAS1a F 5′-GCGAGTTCTCCACCTGCTTCAC-3′ Monkey OAS1a F 5′-ACTAGGCGGATGAGGCTCTTGAG-3′ ORF7 F 5′-AAACCAGTCCAGAGGCAAGG-3′ ORF7 R 5′-GCAAACTACAGTGTAA-3′ F, forward qRT-PCR or Western blotting was used to assess the effect of siRNAs on gene expression and other target gene or protein expression. the cells were seeded in 48-well plates and cultured until the cells reached 70–80% confluences. the cells were then infected or mock infected with PRRSV at an MOI of 1 for 24 h. pGL4.17-basic was used as a control of reporter plasmid. cells were transfected or mock transfected with poly(I:C) for 12 h. the cells were then lysed, and IFN-luciferase activities were measured. the medium was replaced with fresh medium containing the tetrazolium compound. the cells were further incubated at 37°C for 2 h under a humidified atmosphere. the absorbance at 490 nm in each well was recorded using a plate reader. porcine AMs were infected with PRRSV-2 strain HN07-1 for 24 h. then SOCS1-7 and CIS mRNA expressions were assessed. so, the expression kinetics of SOCS1 in several PRRSV-susceptible cells were investigated. PRRSV infection induces SOCS1 expression in porcine AMs and Marc-145 cells. all strains induced SOCS1 mRNA expression. the effects of heat-inactivated and UV-inactivated PRRSV on SOCS1 expression were also investigated. porcine SOCS1 protein levels were assessed using qRT-PCR. at the indicated times, the cells were collected, and SOCS1 mRNA levels were assessed using qRT-PCR. 3.1-SOCS1-His inhibited IFN-–Luc activity induced by poly(I:C)-triggered IFN-–Luc activity. mRNA levels of IFN- and ISGs (ISG56 and OAS1a) were assessed using qRT-PCR. Marc145 cells or CRL2843-CD163 cells were transfected with pcDNA3.1-SOCS1-His. at 24 hpi, the cells were harvested, SOCS1 mRNA levels (A) were assessed using qRT-PCR, and SOCS1 protein levels (B) were assessed using ELISA. induction of SOCS1 expression by PRRSV is independent of type I IFNs. previous studies have shown that PRRSV could induce a certain level of IFN- and IFN- expression in porcine AMs. FN abrogates expression of SOCS1 induced by type I IFNs. despite partial IFNAR1 silencing, SOCS1 was still upregulated by PRRSV. twenty-four hours later, porcine AMs were harvested and analyzed for SOCS1 mRNA (A) quantification using qRT-PCR and SOCS1 protein (B) quantification using ELISA. at 24 hpi, porcine AMs were transfected with 20 nM NC siRNA or siRNA against IFNAR1 for 24 h and then infected with PRRSV (MOI = 1). 2000/100-Luc cells were transfected with the 2000/100-Luc and pRL-TK Renilla luciferase reporter plasmid. twenty-four hours later, the transfected cells were harvested and analyzed for luciferase activity. luciferase activity of the full-length 2000/100-Luc construct exhibited 33.3-fold and 22.3-fold increases over that of pGL4.17-basic in Marc145 cells. porcine SOCS1 promoter–truncated mutants were subcloned into pGL4.17-basic vector and the resulting constructs denoted as 2000/100-Luc, 1359/100-Luc, 381/100-Luc, and 58/100-Luc. the relative lengths and positions of the 5′ ends of these fragments were indicated. Marc-145 cells were cotransfected with plasmid that encodes nsps or structural protein. at 24 h posttransfection, the luciferase activities were assessed. PRRSV N protein induced the highest SOCS1 promoter activity. the cells were harvested for luciferase activity analysis. all experiments were performed with at least three independent replicates. the PRRSV-2 N protein consists of 123 aa and has two nuclear NLS sequences. the AP-1 binding motif in the SOCS1 promoter is indispensable for SOCS1 production Analysis with Proscan V1.7 and Promoter 2.0 revealed that five transcriptional regulatory elements were found in the 381 to 58 region of the SOCS1 promoter. a series of mutants defective in each specific transcription regulatory element were prepared. AP-1 binding site in porcine SOCS1 promoter is indispensable for SOCS1 transcription. AP-1 binding site in porcine SOCS1 promoter was important for PRRSV-induced SOCS1 promoter activity. AP-1 is critical for PRRSV and N-induced SOCS1 promoter activity. porcine AMs were pretreated with a specific c-Jun inhibitor (SR11302) for 1 h prior to HN07-1 infection. twenty-four hours later, SOCS1 mRNA expression was analyzed using qRT-PCR. cytotoxicity of the inhibitor was determined by a cell viability assay. c-Jun phosphorylation was observed when Marc-145 cells were transfected with an expression vector that encodes the PRRSV N protein. the level of phosphorylation of c-Fos was difficult to detect. both PRRSV and the N protein activate the AP-1 pathways. Marc-145 cells were transfected with a vector that encodes the PRRSV N protein at doses of 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0 g per well (six-well pates) they then harvested 48 h later for analysis of SOCS1 and p–c-Jun/c-Jun levels, using Western blotting. the p38 inhibitor SB203580 and the JNK inhibitor SP600125 significantly inhibited SOCS1 expression in porcine AMs. the ERK inhibitor PD98059 had no effect on PRRSV-induced SOCS1 expression. the p38 and JNK MAPK signaling pathways are required for PRRSV upregulation of SOCS1 expression. p38 inhibitor (SB203580) and p38 inhibitor (SP600125) dose-dependently inhibited PRRSV-induced c-Fos and c-Fos phosphorylation in a dose-dependent manner. c-Jun activation by PRRSV is mediated through the JNK pathway and c-Fos activation is mediated through the p38 pathway. plasmid encodes PRRSV N protein at a dose of 2.0 g per well (six-well plates) for 48 h. cells were harvested for analysis of SOCS1 and p–c-Jun/c-Jun expression. an mRNA expressions were assessed. so, the expression kinetics of SOCS1 in several PRRSV-susceptible cells were investigated. the effects of heat-inactivated and UV-inactivated PRRSV on SOCS1 induction were also investigated. all strains induced SOCS1 mRNA expression, which suggests that SOCS1 upregulation was not dependent on PRRSV strains. at indicated times, the cells were collected, and SOCS1 mRNA levels were assessed using qRT-PCR. at the indicated times, the cells were collected, and SOCS1 protein levels were assessed using qRT-PCR. transfection with pcDNA3.1-SOCS1-His inhibited IFN-–Luc activity induced by poly(I:C)-triggered IFN-–Luc activity. porcine AMs were transfected with siRNAs specific for SOCS1 and then infected with HN07-1. overexpression of SOCS1 by transfection of Marc145 cells or CRL2843-CD163 cells with SOCS1 expression constructs (pcDNA3.1-SOCS1-His) dramatically enhanced PRRSV replication. it was concluded PRRSV may hijack the host cell SOCS1 to facilitate its own replication. induction of SOCS1 expression by PRRSV is independent of type I IFNs. previous studies have shown that PRRSV could induce a certain level of IFN- and IFN- expression in porcine AMs. the Marc-145 cells were cotransfected with the plasmid that encodes nsps or structural protein, the luciferase reporter plasmid 381/100-Luc and the pRL-TK Renilla luciferase reporter plasmid. at 24 h posttransfection, the luciferase activities were assessed. the cells were harvested for luciferase activity analysis. all experiments were performed with at least three independent replicates. the PRRSV-2 N protein consists of 123 aa and has two nuclear NLS sequences. the AP-1 binding motif in the SOCS1 promoter is indispensable for SOCS1 production. five transcriptional regulatory elements were found in the 381 to 58 region of the promoter. a series of mutants defective in each specific transcription regulatory element were prepared. AP-1 binding site in porcine SOCS1 promoter is indispensable for SOCS1 transcription. AP-1 binding site in porcine SOCS1 promoter was important for PRRSV-induced SOCS1 promote. porcine AMs were pretreated with a specific c-Jun inhibitor (SR11302) for 1 h prior to HN07-1 infection. twenty-four hours later, SOCS1 mRNA expression was analyzed using qRT-PCR. no concentrations of the inhibitor caused detectable cell death in porcine AMs. the level of phosphorylation of c-Fos in Marc-145 cells was difficult to detect. both PRRSV and the N protein activate the AP-1 pathways. the AP-1 signaling pathway is involved in SOCS1 upregulation. Porcine AMs were infected with HN07-1 (MOI = 1) and harvested at the indicated time points for analysis of SOCS1, p–c-Jun/c-Jun, and p–c-Fos/c-Fos levels. p38/AP-1 and JNK/AP-1 signaling pathways are involved in PRRSV-induced SOCS1 expression. protein levels were assessed using qRT-PCR and ELISA. the p38 inhibitor SB203580 and the JNK inhibitor SP600125 significantly inhibited SOCS1 expression in porcine AMs. the ERK inhibitor PD98059 had no effect on PRRSV-induced SOCS1 expression. p38 inhibitor (SB203580) and p38 inhibitor (SP600125) dose-dependently inhibited PRRSV-induced c-Fos and c-Fos phosphorylation in a dose-dependent manner. c-Jun activation by PRRSV is mediated through the JNK pathway and c-Fos activation is mediated through the p38 pathway. the cells were harvested for analysis of SOCS1 and p–c-Jun/c-Jun expression. the cells were then transfected with plasmid that encodes the PRRSV N protein at a dose of 2.0 g per well (six-well plates) for 48 h. p38 and JNK were involved in N protein–induced SOCS1 expression. PRRSV upregulation by PRRSV was not fully dependent on type I IFNs. it was involved in p38/AP-1 and JNK/AP-1 signaling pathways. it was further proven that NLS-2 of N protein played a critical role in SOCS1 promoter activation. i on porcine AMs or 6 and 12 hpi on Marc-145 cells exhibited slightly decreased effects (Fig. 1A, 1E) SOCS1 upregulation is a beneficial host response to PRRSV infection. the multifunctional PRRSV N protein is the most abundant viral protein in infected cells. the N protein suppressed IFN- expression through inhibition of IRF3 phosphorylation and nuclear translocation. the results show that PRRSV N protein also plays an important role in SOCS1 expression. AP-1 and JNK/AP-1 signaling pathway involved in SOCS1 production. signaling pathways used for SOCS1 induction by PRRSV and N protein differed.
